intro: Acalypha karsteniana, commonly known as the velvetleaf or karsten's spurge, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It is characterized by its striking, colorful bracts that range from red to purple, which are often mistaken for flowers. The plant has simple, opposite leaves that are usually covered in fine hairs, giving it a soft, velvety texture. It produces small, inconspicuous yellow flowers that are clustered in dense inflorescences. Acalypha karsteniana is often cultivated as an ornamental plant due to its vibrant foliage and unique appearance.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acalypha karsteniana is primarily native to tropical and subtropical regions of Central and South America. It is commonly found in lowland areas but can also occur in higher elevations up to around 1,000 meters. Its distribution is closely linked to humid climates with well-drained soils.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha karsteniana was mainly introduced to ornamental horticulture and landscaping due to its attractive foliage and unique growth habit.
